passage:
(1) Bartering is one of the oldest methods of exchange, dating back thousands of years before the invention of currency. It involves trading goods and services directly without using money as an intermediary. Though simple in concept, bartering allowed early civilizations to obtain resources they could not produce themselves and helped forge connections between different communities and regions.

(2) The basic principle of bartering is straightforward: two parties agree to exchange items of similar perceived value. For example, a farmer might trade excess crops for tools made by a blacksmith. Unlike monetary transactions, bartering requires a 'double coincidence of wants,' meaning both parties must desire what the other offers. This limitation sometimes made traditional bartering inefficient, as people had to search extensively for suitable trading partners.

(3) Despite its challenges, bartering systems became quite sophisticated in some ancient societies. The Mesopotamians, Phoenicians, and early Egyptians all developed elaborate networks where goods like grain, olive oil, and textiles were commonly exchanged. Some communities even created standardized values for commonly traded items, which helped facilitate more complex multi-party exchanges. In these systems, certain goods like salt, tea, or shells sometimes functioned as primitive forms of currency.

(4) Bartering continues to exist in modern times, particularly during economic hardships when currency loses value or becomes scarce. During the Great Depression, many Americans returned to bartering when cash was limited. Similarly, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, many citizens in the resulting countries relied on barter exchanges while their new currencies stabilized. Some rural communities around the world still regularly supplement monetary exchanges with bartering arrangements.

(5) Today, bartering has even adapted to the digital age. Online platforms allow people to exchange goods and services without cash, creating modern bartering communities. These systems often use credit systems to overcome the double coincidence of wants problem. Bartering also remains popular among businesses looking to conserve cash, with companies trading everything from advertising space to professional services. Despite the dominance of money in modern economies, the ancient practice of direct exchange continues to offer a resilient alternative method for people to trade value.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct verb tense.

options.A: He has gone to the store yesterday.
options.B: She have been studying for three hours.
options.C: They are watching a movie right now.
options.D: We did finished our homework already.

options.D: If it raining tomorrow, we will stay at home.
